title: can you spot owl camouflaged stone wall
story: Derbyshire-based photographer Village Jim captured the little bird in a series of striking images bound to have people squinting desperately to find it.Only eagle-eyed viewers will be able to spot the small grey bird perched on the wall in one particularly tricky photo.At a closer glance the rugged line of grey transforms to reveal the Little Owl sitting stock still about a third of the way down the stones.It could be taking a short nap, safe in the knowledge its hard to find, or simply surveying its adopted home.In another shot the bird is seen on the top of the wall with a few pals.They are much easier to spot as they jut above the solid line of grey stones, but still blend in with the colour of their feathers.The family appear to have found the perfect spot to shelter, amongst the ancient wall that snakes through a field.And it looks like they are quite at home in the surroundings, as the photographer also captured a shot of one of the owls sitting on the roof of an old barn.Little Owls can be found throughout England and Wales, with some seen in southern Scotland.They like lowland farmland with hedges and copses - so this Derbyshire field with ious forms of shelter is ideal.Little Owls are closely associated with mythology, specifically the Greek goddess Athena and the Roman goddess Minerva - representing wisdom and knowledge.Camouflage is natures gift, designed to keep these creatures safe from predators - and can make them invisible to the human eye.We have reported on other animals blending in to their surroundings, as they hide in plain sight.

title: silicon valley preparing apocalypse nuke bunkers new zealand
story: Seven tech billionaires have so far made apocalyptic investments in the commonwealth country in case they need to flee California.Fear of nuclear war, violent revolution and pandemics has seen San Francisco’s finest start commissioning multi million pound underground bunkers in New Zealand.Made by Texas based bunker manufacturer Rising S Company, the 150-tonne bunkers are buried 13 feet underground.The company’s general manager describes New Zealand as the ideal location to ride out the apocalypse.Gary Lynch told Bloomberg: “New Zealand is an enemy of no one. Its not a nuclear target. Its not a target for war. Its a place where people seek refuge.”Their top of the range bunker, The Aristocrat costs £8.9 million excluding the installation fee.It has a capacity for more than 50 people in ying degrees of luxury and features bullet proof doors, a solar generated charging system, a swimming poll, bowling lane and gun range, amongst other luxuries.Even an ex- Kiwi Prime Minister has noticed the uptick in interest from wealthy Americans in his country as an escape plan.John Key, who was New Zealand’s PM from 2008-2016, said: “Ive had a lot of people say to me that they would like to own a property in New Zealand if the world goes to hell in a hand basket.”The two most recent 990 square feet bunkers sent to the nation from the States were each taken on 19 trailers having been split into sections.One was installed in the North Island of New Zealand while the other was secreted away in the even more sparsely populated South Island.Paypal co-founder, and Facebook billionaire, Peter Thiel built a £3.7 million home in Queenstown New Zealand complete with a panic room.His buddy, and fellow entrepreneur, Sam Altman also let slip that he has plans to catch a flight out there if a pandemic ever hits.And LinkedIn co-founder Reid Hoffman told The New Yorker last year that, “saying you’re ‘buying a house in New Zealand’ is kind of a wink, wink, say no more”.Other wealthy US entrepreneurs who have bought properties in the country include film director James Cameron and billionaire hedge fund manager Julian Robinson.A total of 17 Americans took advantage of the New Zealand’s Investor Plus Visa - which requires a 10million investment over 36 months – last year.But it is believed that the rush of investment from billionaires fearing the worst could have been one of the motivating factors behind a new law banning many foreigners from buying homes.Fortunately New Zealand isn’t the only place the super-rich have looked to to ride out the End of Days.Luxurious bolt holes to ride out the nuclear winter have sprung up, or rather burrowed under, across the US and EuropeYour father or grandfathers bunker was not very comfortable, Robert Vicino, the CEO of high-end shelter company Vivos, told CNN.They were grey. They were metal, like a ship or something military. And the truth is mankind cannot survive long-term in such a Spartan, bleak environment.It may seem like an over-the-top purchase designed for the super-paranoid - but sports stars, hedge fund managers and even tech gurus including Bill Gates are rumoured to have invested in bunkers.Trident Lakes survival community and country club offers condos that are 90 per cent sheltered with lagoons, a golf course and equestrian centre above groundBut while some want to bunker down alone with their loved ones, other companies have cashed in on our desire to be in a community - and feel closer to the real world, even in the face of disaster.Missile silos and military bunkers have been transformed into condos and underground villages - complete with cinemas, swimming pools and leisure areas.Vivos Xpoint, in South Dakota, is made up of 575 military bunkers - and is being developed to accommodate 5,000 people.The bomb-proof holiday homes cost between £20,000 and £160,000, while the underground village will include a cinema, classroom, gardens, doctors surgery, spa and gym.The company also offer a modern day Noahs Ark, in a former Cold War-era munitions storage facility in Germany, which includes 34 properties sized between 2,500 and 5,000 square feet.This particular shelter will include a tram network to transport residents to the bunkers restaurants, coffee shops, pool, cinema and game rooms.We have all the comforts of home, but also the comforts that you expect when you leave your home, Robert added.

title: locals complain oxford city council resurface posh end street
story: The new tarmac runs to the spot where a spike-topped wall once divided council houses from the rich households down the road in Oxford.The suburban street is still split into two ends where the wealthy Wentworth Road meets the less affluent Aldrich Road in Sunnymead.Following a row with Oxford City Council the dividing wall was demolished 60 years ago.But now a stark reminder of the past appeared on the road when workers repaired only the posh end.An angry vandal armed with a spray can tagged the words class war on to the gleaming new tarmac in protest.Naomi Langlais, who lives on the working class end of the street, said: It was around April or May time that they decided the middle class side deserved to be resurfaced.So we waited patiently for our end to be resurfaced too and thought it was just taking time as they had run out of money or something.But we soon realised it was just the one end they were doing, apparently we should put up with potholes and uneven surfacing.The mum-of-four added: We have not moved on at all - now we have a visual divide but much less obvious one.It is just so weird it stops at the exact spot that used to occupy the wall, half way down the road.The resurfacing is desperately needed on our end as well.It does make you feel second class and it is no longer a council estate, people have paid a lot of money for houses this end.A plaque now sits on the house which neighboured the wall, and reads: Here stood one of the two Cutteslowe Walls erected 1934 and finally demolished on March 9, 1959.Oxford City Council said the reason that its services company only resurfaced one side of the divide is that Wentworth and Aldrich are still classed as separate roads.A spokesman for the city council said: The structural condition was far worse in Wentworth Road and this led to the decision to resurface this road first.Wentworth and Aldrich are different roads and the need to resurface Wentworth was greater.Oxford Direct Services will be inspecting Aldrich Road to assess the need for pothole repair.

title: mona lisa smile caused under active thyroid
story: US based experts now think the smirk was caused by an under-active thyroid gland.Known as hypothyroidism it can cause swollen hands, thinning hair and a lump in the neck - all visible in the portrait.According to new research this was the condition triggered the enigmatic facial expression of Leonardo da Vincis famous model.It was spurred by not eating enough dairy products, seafood and meat - and her earlier pregnancy.The smile may be due to disability caused by muscle weakness, US medics suggested.Professor of Medicine Dr Mandeep Mehra, medical director of the Heart &amp Vascular Centre at Brigham and Womens Hospital in Boston, said: The enigma of the Mona Lisa can be resolved by a simple medical diagnosis of a hypothyroidism-related illness.In many ways, it is the allure of the imperfections of disease that give this masterpiece its mysterious reality and charm.Previous examinations of the 16th century masterpiece have suggested she was suffering high cholesterol, heart disease - or even syphilis.But Prof Mehra and colleague Dr Hilary Campbell of the California University in Santa Barbara said this is not possible owing to the fact she lived to the age of 63.The limited treatments available at the time would have meant she would have died much younger.Instead the new analysis published in Mayo Clinic Proceedings reveals noblewoman Lisa Gherardini - widely believed to be the subject - displays classic signs of hypothyroidism.Her hands look swollen and it appears shes losing her hair. She also has yellowed skin and what seems to be a goiter - or lump - in the neck.Hypothyroidism in which the thyroid gland does not produce enough hormones can cause all these symptoms.The researchers said: The painting suggests a yellowish discolouration of the skin, which is known to occur in hypothyroidism.The black veil that hangs below what appears to be a large forehead indicates a receding hair line, with hair that appears to be thinned.A complete lack of eyebrows or other hair throughout the pale skin further supports this diagnosis, and cascading hair down the side appears coarse in character.Curiously, a close look at the neck does insinuate the possible presence of a diffuse enlargement such as a goiter.They said swelling in the right hand further supports the theory as this is often noted in advanced stages of hypothyroidism.LISA Gherardini is thought to have posed for the painting between 1503 and 1506.She is believed to have been born in Florence in 1479.At the age of 16 she became the second wife of a wealthy silk merchant, Francesco del Giocondo, with whom she had five children.She became a nun after his death and moved into the SantOrsola convent, a Franciscan monastery.She stayed there for the last four years of her life and is believed to have died in the convent in 1542 and to have been buried near the altar.The portrait that came to be known as the Mona Lisa now hangs in the Louvre Museum in Paris.It was completed by Leonardo in 1506 when she was about 24.Subsequently, the painting was taken to France in 1516 and adorned the court of King Francis I until its permanent display in the Louvre in 1797.Its believed Francesco Del Giocondo commissioned the portrait to celebrate the birth of their child, Andrea, in 1502.The researchers said: In this circumstance, if Lisa Gherardini was indeed suffering from severe hypothyroidism or its consequences, the mysterious smile may at one level be representative of some psychomotor retardation and muscle weakness leading to a less than fully blossomed smile.The condition can be caused by a lack of iodine - found in dairy products, seafood, meat, bread and eggs.This was a common problem among Italians during the Renaissance. Resulting goiters were commonly depicted in paintings and sculptures.The researchers said: Thus, the diet was one that was often iodine deficient and more importantly, the eating habits promoted the development of goiters.Dr Mehra and Dr Campbell also pointed out Lisa Gherardini gave birth shortly before she began sitting for da Vinci.Pregnancy can also contribute to inflaming the gland.

title: theresa mays african boogies have made her a dancing icon as 5000 people sign up to event to learn the prime ministers moves
story: A Facebook page for the “Learn to Dance Like Theresa May Day” in Liverpool has proved wildly popular after coverage of her trade trip last week was dominated by her awkward jiving.It even has a guide so you can emulate the dance, with mocking suggestions such as getting into the “T-Rex” pose and then swinging your arms “in a jerky motion as if trying to prove to your parents you are sober”.Similar events have been arranged in other cities for the same day, although it is unclear how many people are actually planning on attending.The posts also offer handy instructions so people can perfect the moves showcased by Mrs May at home too.It suggests people: “Start walking forward in a slow, mechanical fashion out of time to the music and with arms still positioned like the large dinosaur, but with torso waving like a tree in a mild breeze.”The PM sparked this situation when she was filmed joining in a dance with a group of schoolchildren in Cape Town last week.And when she left South Africa for Nairobi she took her dancing shoes with her, and was seen getting very involved with a group of Kenyan scouts.Her bizarre dancing was compared to the Inbetweeners and footballer Peter Crouch, famous for his robot celebration.The former England star mocked her “picking apples” routine, adding: “Shes going straight through my repertoire on this trip.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: south korea worlds lowest birth rate
story: According to a new study, the country is facing a “disaster” as the fertility rate is tipped to fall as low as 0.96 this year – which is the first time it has ever been below 1.0.Policy makers are worried about future economic and social problems as the quota needed to keep a population stable is 2.1 per woman, to replace her and her partner.South Korea faces looming demographic challenges with a rapidly ageing population, reports News.au.The country’s woeful birth numbers has been caused by people wanting to marry and have kids later in life amid worries over living costs.Another contributing factor is the countrys women focusing on developing their careers, according to the study commissioned by newspaper Chosun Ilbo.The trend has been exacerbated by worsening job prospects for young people and rising property prices.Government officials are worried that welfare schemes such as healthcare and pensions will face shortfalls as society ages and there are fewer people to pay to support them.But efforts to reverse the trend have had little effect.Between 2006 and 2018, the government rolled out initiatives like free child care and cash payments to pregnant women but such policies have failed to lift the birth rate.“This is approaching disaster levels,” Lee Bong-joo of Seoul National University told  this week.“Focusing only on childcare won’t be effective in the future - increasing gender equality in the home and the workplace is the best solution, but that will take time.”In the latest annual census, the working-age population, defined as those aged 15 to 64, fell by 116,000 in 2017 to 36.2 million.Government department Statistics Korea said it was the first time the figure had fallen.National figures released last month showed South Korean births plummeting 12 per cent in 2017 to 357,771, an all-time low.The fertility rate — the number of children a woman can be expected to have in a lifetime — also dropped to a record low of 1.05.Other countries in the region, notably Japan, have experienced depressed fertility rates in recent years but South Korea now has the lowest.Comparatively, Australia’s fertility rate continues to hover just below the replacement rate.Except for a brief time when it rate reached 2.00 in 2009, it has remained around 1.8 since 2006.A version of this article originally appeared on News.au.

title: brexit no deal leaked operation yellowhammer
story: John Glen was seen in Downing Street carrying confidential documents which give away details of the operation.The papers show that ministers wont be offered extra cash to prepare for Brexit in the event of No Deal - and will have to make savings instead.Mr Glen, a Treasury Minister, was apparently given the documents at a briefing earlier this week.They reveal the name given to the Governments contingency planning for No Deal - Operation Yellowhammer.The name refers to a type of bird and was apparently choasen at random by Whitehall officials.The plans are being handled by the Civil Contingencies Secretariat - part of the Cabinet Office which is supposed to deal with disasters such as terror attacks and floods.They show that Government departments are expected to raise the money they need to pay for No Deal by internal reprioritisation - i.e. cutting expenditure in other areas.But ministers can also ask the Treasury for extra cash next year to cope with Brexit-related costs.The secret papers also make reference to plans which are intended to keep planes and trains travelling between Britain and the continent even without a Brexit deal.Labour MP Ben Bradshaw, a backer of the pro-EU Peoples Vote campaign, said: “With the Operation Yellowhammer revelation, we now know the Government is preparing for Brexit in the same way they’d approach catastrophes like flooding, a disease outbreak or a terrorist attack. This is not what anyone voted for in 2016.“We were promised ‘sunlit uplands’, but what’s being delivered instead is a public policy disaster with severe implications for the future of our country.

title: ancient church that once stood in the historic city of nicaea found submerged in a turkish lake 1600 years later
story: The ruined Christian church discovered in Turkeys Lake Iznik is believed to have been built around 390 AD.The church lies ten feet below the water, about 160 feet from the shore of Lake Iznik, historically known as Nicaea where a Christian creed was adopted in 325 AD.Professor Mustafa Şahin, the head of archaeology at Bursa Uludağ University, said: When I first saw the images of the lake, I was quite surprised to see a church structure that clearly.I was doing field surveys in Iznik [since 2006], and I hadnt discovered such a magnificent structure like that.He believes the church marks the place where Saint Neophytos was martyred in 303 AD and that it was built in his honour.Archaeologists have excavated parts of the underwater site since 2015, using a system of powerful vacuum nozzles.The nozzles removes soil from the underwater site and transports it to the shore, where it can be carefully sifted for artefacts.He said the church may have been built on top of a pagan temple to Apollo, a Greek and Roman sun god sometimes associated with Jesus in the early Christian period.In A.D. 740, an earthquake destroyed the church, which later sank beneath the lakes surface, leaving the ruins submerged and forgotten until they were rediscovered.Profesor Şahin and local government leader Alinur Aktaş have now called for the site to be established as Turkeys first underwater archaeological museum.If the plans for the underwater museum are approved, construction could begin this year and it would open to visitors in 2019, Professor Şahin said.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: aly ross x factor ayda
story: It’s a dangerous half- truth which seriously under-estimates the woman.So it should be pointed out, as a matter of urgency, that Ayda Field was elevated to the hot spot because she’s very close friends with Simon ­Cowell’s girlfriend Laura ­Silverman as well.Understood? Good. Then let’s proceed, in an open-minded fashion, with X Factor, the focus group years, where there are some new faces on the panel.We’ve got Louis “lad” Tomlinson, who brings the experience of taking part in the show.Robbie Williams, who brings the ­experience of over 20 years in the music industry.And Ayda, who brings the ­experience of playing Angela Moroni in Days Of Our Lives.Ironically, though, the newest face of all probably belongs to Simon Cowell, whose head now requires constant fanning and is so curiously swollen they could shove it on a plinth in the FA Museum above a plaque that reads: “1923 Cup Final ­football.”What caused it to balloon, I cannot say for sure, but if it was done to divert attention from the other end of the judging panel, he’s seriously underestimated the attention-seeking and self-absorption of Robbie Williams, which is total.A factor not helped by the adoring presence of Ayda, whose public displays of affection for “Rob” could quickly become the X Factor’s most nauseating ever detail.Enormous as it is, there’s not much Simon’s head can do about the singing either.The problem here, of course, is that almost everyone who wants to audition for a karaoke show has now auditioned, or sung professionally.So we were swamped with re-treads on this weekend’s double-header.Among them were: Danny Tetley, who appeared on Pop Idol, Caribbean ­talent show ­veteran Olatunji Yearwood, who’s already got a record deal, Livin’ Joy’s Janice “Dreamer” Robinson, and Brendan ­Murray from Hometown, a Sony act who were managed by Louis Walsh. Not that anyone was admitting as much.If there was any joy and spontaneity to proceedings, though, it was generally ­provided by those random whack-nut contestants who don’t appear on Simon’s approved list.Acts like Livia and the Elementals, Aaron Denham, who looked like he’d absconded from Guantanamo Bay, and Andy Hofton, who performed a song called Castle Of Love that’s been 20 years in gestation and, to no tune at all, went like this.“All my life, I’ve been building a castle of love. That lifts me to your heart.“Here I am, I’ve built my castle of . . .”“Andy! ANDY!” Simon’s hand of objection went up. He was then asked if he had a second song. Angels kicked in and I think you know what happened next.If someone on the judging panel had their wits about them, obviously, they’d have waited for Andy and Robbie to finish their duet then said: “Actually, let’s try Castle Of Love again.”No chance of that, though, as Cowell set his stall out, day one, when he told Danny Tetley: “The music business should be more open-minded.”The irony of a show that’s spent 14 series steering viewers towards its preferred winner now demanding open-mindedness won’t be lost on anyone, but I think it’s just ­cosmetic.The sort of “let’s-pretend we’re-nice” ­cobblers political parties trot out when they’re in as much trouble as this show.It won’t work, though. ’Cos there were so many things the X Factor urgently needed to ditch — sob stories, manipulation, product-placement, deception, scripted “spontaneity” — yet it sounds like the only element it’s going to discard is the brutal and funny honesty which made it stand out from the competition.Show’s over, folks.Paul Merson: “The one person I feel sorry for is the Newcastle fans.”And Tony Cottee: “Hemed’s had two efforts, Freeman’s had two efforts and all three have been saved.”CELEBRITY Big Brother viewers finally got to see last week why the show paid £75,000 to book actress Roxanne Pallett, whose relationship with the truth could, at best, be described as flexible.Unwitting victim was Corrie’s Ryan Thomas, who engaged her with a spot of the house craze for shadow boxing on Thursday’s show, which everyone could see was entirely playful.Having initially laughed it off, though, Roxanne suddenly decided it was “an assault” and he was “a woman beater”, who had to be removed.It made a mockery of the real thing, obviously, and would have ruined Ryan’s life if there’d been a hint of doubt about the video footage.In the kangaroo court atmosphere of the #MeToo movement, however, and with a £75,000 investment to protect, Channel 5 had to indulge her fantasies and give Ryan an official warning for his “behaviour”.She’s since fled the house, of course, without her fee, and apologised.If anyone’s missing Roxanne’s histrionics, though, there’ll soon be another chance to see the dingbat lose her s**t on Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls, where her stay comes to a tearful climax over the camp fire which, apparently, sparks fevered memories of a teenage house inferno that could’ve killed her entire family. But didn’t.It’s a pattern likely to continue as well.Given the fact then that reality television clearly causes Roxanne Pallett such huge emotional distress and painful memory spasms, it’s probably best if neither she nor the toxic show that booked her ever troubles us again.BBC2’s Eight Go Rallying, in ­CambodiaBBC1’s Bodyguard is a curse, a liability, a Jonah. Norman bloody Wisdom in a bullet-proof vest.He sits on a train, ­suicide bombers appear in the next carriage.He gets in a car with the Home Secretary, a sniper’s killed Terry the driver.He turns up to see her speak? KABOOM! The front three rows of the ­theatre suddenly explode.Where Sergeant David Budd goes, trouble ­immediately follows.And still no one at MI5 or Scotland Yard has made the connection.Mind you, it took the best brains at the Met several days to work out the sniper, who had a shot on him like Yul Brynner in The Magnificent Seven, “might be ex-Forces”.Yeah, well, it’s not a bad theory, I suppose, though you couldn’t rule out the possibility they’ll haul in David Blunkett for questioning next week, as this lot all seem to have trained with Walford CID, the world’s stupidest police force.It’s just one of several reasons why I’m still not buying into Bodyguard.The others being, its idiotic levels of political correctness, the stilted performance of Richard Madden as Budd, and his entirelyunbelievable relationship with Keeley Hawes’ Julia Montague.Mind you, she did conjure up an even more far-fetched and disturbing possibility on Sunday night when she told him: “Sex with the Home Secretary, it’s a heinous crime.”Sex with the Shadow Home Secretary. A lock him up and throw away the key crime.MEANWHILE, on Age Before Beauty, Ivy-Rae: “We need to do something so bad that they’ll still end up sweating in 20 years’ time.”Mission accomplished. Now please stop.“You’re all going up the mountain?”“Yes.”You can’t teach this stuff.Sent in by Renee E, from Cleethorpes, Lincs. Picture research: Marta Ovod.LOOSE Women, Janet Street-Porter: “I’ve decided, when I go over to the other side, put my body in a bag, ship me down to the crematorium, frizzle me down and then . . . ” Scatter her ashes by the finishing post at Catterick. The rest is glue.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: apples takeover of shazam cleared by eu
story: This is mainly because Apple - currently the second-largest player in the market behind Spotify - would obtain commercially sensitive data about rivals' customers by owning Shazam.But the commission ruled on Thursday that the merged entity would not have a unique advantage and Apple's competitors would still have the opportunity to access and use similar databases.It also found Apple would not be able to shut out competing providers by restricting access to Shazam.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"The EU's competition commissioner, Margrethe Vestager, said: "Data is key in the digital economy. story: NewsMembers of suspended Stormont Assembly will have their pay docked because they are not performing all their functionsTheir salaries will be cut in November from £49,500 to £35,888Share&nbspByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent12:13, 6 SEP 2018Updated12:14, 6 SEP 2018NewsSecretary of State Karen Bradley said they are not performing all their functions "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStormont Assembly members' pay will be reduced by more than &pound13,000 as they are not performing all their functions, Secretary of State Karen Bradley said. Northern Ireland's devolved legislature in Belfast has not sat since early last year in a row over identity issues like the Irish language, which has prevented the appointment of ministers. Repeated negotiations convened by the British and Irish governments have failed to persuade former coalition partners the Democratic Unionists and Sinn Fein to reconcile their differences. title: tory northern ireland secretary admits
story: NewsTory Northern Ireland Secretary admits she didn't understand basics of Northern Irish politicsShe admitted that at the time she did not fathom some of the deep-rooted issues which define Northern Irish politicsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter20:00, 6 SEP 2018Updated20:04, 6 SEP 2018NewsNorthern Ireland Secretary Karen Bradley "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Tory Northern Ireland Secretary has admitted she didn’t understand the basics of Northern Irish politics when Theresa May gave her the job. Karen Bradley had no idea the country’s nationalists did not vote for unionist parties in elections. Ms Bradley was given the job earlier this year, in a reshuffle that saw her moved from the Culture department. But she today admitted that at the time she did not fathom some of the deep-rooted issues which define Northern Irish politics.  Ms Bradley also used the interview to slap down Brexit backers - including Boris Johnson - who claim the border issue is being used for a lack of progress in Brexit talks.  She told The House magazine: I didn't understand things like when elections are fought for example in Northern Ireland - people who are nationalists don't vote for unionist parties and vice-versa.  So, the parties fight for election within their own community. Actually, the unionist parties fight the elections against each other in unionist communities and nationalists in nationalist communities. Jenny Chapman, Labour's Shadow Brexit Minister said: This is embarrassing from the Northern Ireland Secretary.  Given this worrying lack of basic knowledge about Northern Ireland's history, it's no wonder the Tories don't seem to understand the vital importance of preventing a return of a hard border there. Ms Bradley was appointed in January after her predecessor James Brokenshire stepped aside for medical reasons. She continued: That's a very different world from the world I came from, where in Staffordshire Moorlands I was fighting a Labour-held seat as a Conservative politician and I was trying to put forward why you would want to switch from voting Labour to voting Conservative. That is so incredibly different and it's when you realise that, and you see that, that you can then start to understand some of the things that the politicians say and some of the rhetoric.

title: treasury no deal brexit document
story: NewsTreasury no-deal Brexit document 'Operation Yellowhammer' accidentally revealed by bungling ministerOnce again sensitive documents have been photographed on Downing Street - here's what they say and what it could meanShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter13:55, 6 SEP 2018NewsThe document outlines Treasury plans for no-deal "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOnce again, a bungling minister has been photographed holding sensitive Government documents on Downing Street - accidentally revealing their contents to the world.  This time it was Treasury minister John Glen, who was photographed leaving a meeting this morning holding a document revealing details of contingency plans for a no deal Brexit - dubbed Project Yellowhammer.  The document appears to be a planning sheet for a meeting - it's dated September 4th  - but it's unclear whether that's the date of the meeting or the date the document was written. Here's what we can make out from the document and what it could mean.  Here's the visible text of the document    Operation Yellowhammer: no deal contingency planning  Summary of issue   This meeting will consider progress on the Government’s plans for mitigating the immediate impacts of a No Deal Brexit. The Civil Contingencies Secretariat held a two-day workshop last week to review departments’ plans, assumptions, interdependencies and next steps.    HMT  objectives     Emphasise the importance of building a XWH  communications architecture that can help maintain confidence in the event of contingency plans being triggered - particularly important for financial services.  Explain that departments should be raising Yellowhammer costs through the normal channels - through their spending teams for in-year pressures and in their bids for 19/20 Brexit allocations for spending in that year. Their first call should be internal reprioritisation. Reaffirm the need for consistent planning assumptions across plans [unreadable] aviation and rail access to the EU. Remind departments of the need to consider the financial [unreadable] commercial firms that play a role in their contingency plans.

title: westminster dog year winners revealed
story: NewsWestminster Dog of the Year winners revealed as 'Corbyn' wins landslide popular voteThe seven-month-old pup gained the most votes in a public or pawblic poll for the Westminster Dog of the Year.Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent16:25, 6 SEP 2018Updated16:50, 6 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/politics/video/corbyn-won-important-westminster-vote-13202145,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Cockapoo named Corbyn has won an important vote in Westminster by a landslide. The seven-month-old pup gained the most votes in a public or pawblic poll for the Westminster Dog of the Year. Mike Amesbury, who is Labour MP for Weaver Vale, and shadow minister for employment was chuffed to have topped the pawblic poll with the canine Corbyn. The Kennel Club organises the annual event, which this year was raising awareness of how fireworks can affect dogs. Some MPs brought their own dogs to compete but others appeared alongside rescue dogs to promote adopting a pet. Only Labour and Conservative MPs took part this year with Labour topping both the public poll and the judges' pick. The overall winner or winners of the prestigious award of Westminster Dog of the Year was Alex Norris MP with border collies Boomer and Corona. Winner of the Pawblic Vote - Corbyn and Mike Amesbury  Corbyn the Cockapoo was named by Mike Amesbury's son after his dad won his Weaver Vale. He said: My son was 7 at the time and it was an election promise by my wife who told him 'if your dad wins the election we'll get a puppy'. Amesbury ousted the Tory incumbent in a shock win. I think it surprised Amanda I won the election and I'm a politician that lived up to his promise, he said. Ted named his dog Corbyn, he loves the White Stripes theme tune as well as well as the fact that his dad's a Labour MP as well. Mike was persuaded to enter the competition by his Labour colleague Tracey Brabin who won the competition with her dog Rocky last year. He said: Obviously you're highlighting very important issues, I've only been in Parliament a short period of time, but I've campaigned on dog shock collars and we've been working together across the political parties.  We're a nation of animal lovers, especially dogs and constituents often get in touch to highlight issues. We're shipping ious breeds, valuable breeds into this country, so it'll be clamping down on that.  This year's theme is strengthening regulation around fireworks as it's a very distressing time for dogs and pets in general. We want to encourage people to go to organised displays instead. Westminster Dog of the Year - Alex Norris with Boomer and Corona  Alex Norris told the Mirror that Corona is terrified of fireworks. The MP for Nottingham North has a special fire proof covering over his letter box in case people try to post burning material through his door.   He said that one year he and the family had gone out to a display. When they returned he said: The fire proof bag is by its nature an indestructible thing. Corona had absolutely obliterated the thing and normally he's a very placid dog. 2nd Place  Andrew Mitchell proudly showed off his Welsh Springer Spaniel Scarlet. She is six years old and the former Government whip described her as a loyal dog who loves cuddles and kisses and gives her paw if she wants more strokes. 3rd Place Dame Cheryl Gillian and Gooseberry Cheryl Gillian struggled to persuade Gooseberry of the merits of jumping over the obstacle course. She said she entered with a Dogs Trust Rescue dog because sadly I do not have a dog of my own at the momen and every dog deserves a good home. Dame Cheryl is trying to raise awareness of puppy farming and unscrupulous breeding. Sue Hayman and Greyhound Hugo who is a Dogs Trust Rescue Dog  Sue told us she had left her own dog at home in her Workington seat in Cumbria because it was too far for him to travel. Hugo is a two-year-old greyhound who has been retired from racing and is looking for a new home. The shadow DEFRA secretary said: I'm here today to support the work Dogs Trust is doing - fantastic work because there are so many dogs who need help and support - need new forever homes. It would be lovely if Hugo could find somewhere because he's absolutely gorgeous and he's been so well behaved, she said. He's done some jumps with me and we've been through the slalom, he's done everything I asked of him - he couldn't have done any better.   Anna Turley and her Shih Tzu Clem  The MP for Redcar was proudly showing off her Shih Tzu Clem who was named after Labour leader Clement Attlee. Anna Turley said she was also there in memory of Baby, a bulldog who was severely abused by two of her constituents and her campaign to change the sentencing for animal cruelty. We're raising awareness for the campaign I've been running for the last couple of years on animal cruelty and to increase the sentencing from six months to five years. I had a terrible case in my constituency of Baby the bulldog - a dog who was abused, thrown down the stairs stamped on - ultimately had to be put down and the guys filmed themselves laughing while they abused the dog. And they got away with just a small fine and an electronic tag. I looked into it and I realised the legislation hadn't been changed since 1911, which was originally about flogging dead horses on the street.  It certainly wasn't meant for something so horrendous as something as this case. So I've been campaigning, I had a private members' bill last year, pressured the Government and was delighted when Michael Gove announced last year he was going to increase the animal sentencing t five years but here we are a year on still waiting for it come through. Jo Platt with Lurcher Pam who is a Dogs Trust Rescue Dog  Jo Platt, who is MP for Leigh, did not want to say goodbye to Pam after spending the day with the beautiful Lurcher who is currently living at the Dogs Trust in Basildon, Essex. Pam was adopted by a family who had two pugs and when the dogs didn't get on - they decided to let Pam go. Ms Platt said: They're associated with needing a lot of exercise but they're fantastic family dogs they're so loving and they're crossed with collies Lurchers so they're really, really clever dogs. Ms Platt is campaigning for greater regulation at rescue centres and animal sanctuaries. Environment Secretary and Muffin were a no show  Labour's Anna Turley was disappointed as she wanted to bend his ear about speeding up the changes to sentences for animal cruelty.

title: baby born looking like ready
story: NewsBaby born looking like ‘ready-to-eat counter chicken’ with her legs flung forward and feet beside her shouldersLittle Willow's birth position puzzled doctors and mum Lily Paziuk, 20, who has dubbed her daughter her 'little chicken'Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJessica CrippsAmber Hicks11:34, 6 SEP 2018NewsWillow Flather-Paziuk stunned doctors and her mum "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new mum who noticed her baby daughter was always covering her face during scan photos was stunned to realise it wasn't with her hands - but instead her legs. And doctors were even more flabbergasted when little Willow Flather-Paziuk arrived into the world in the position of a ‘ready-to-eat counter chicken’. The flexible tot had her legs flung forward and feet beside her shoulders puzzling mum Lily Paziuk, 20, who now believes she has a mini gymnast on her hands. “I had no idea babies could be born like that, said Lily, from Cleckheaton, West Yorkshire. I thought her feet were back to front at first and wondered what was going on.  Doting mum Lily has even affectionately dubbed her daughter ‘little chicken’ because of the position’s hilarious likeness to a cooked chicken. Thankfully Willow, now one month old, was unharmed and has returned her legs to a more normal position over the course of three weeks. However, she still prefers to sleep with her legs by her sides with her ankles by her shoulders in a split to rival an experienced gymnast. Her mum was delighted when an ultrasound confirmed that Willow’s hips were fine and undamaged by the surprising position. Lily said: “We call her little chicken because she still puts her legs out to the side all the time, even in the position she sleeps in. She does just look like a little chicken.  “Because I had her by caesarean, I didn’t see her straight away so I had no idea. “The doctors were shocked. I was quite out of it but I do remember they were all quite shocked. “I could hear them all talking about it but I didn’t know what they were on about. They were all calling her a little gymnast. “When I got back on the ward all the midwives were laughing that they couldn’t get her feet in the baby grow. “It was definitely a big surprise for me to see her. I went to change her nappy for the first time and they just sprung out. I was like ‘oh my god’. “It was like the elephant in the room because I had loads of visitors come and see us and her legs would spill out and no one dared ask about it.  “It’ll definitely be a joke as she grows older. I’ll never let her forget it. She added: “I think she’ll be very flexible. She can still get back into that position even now. “When I go to change her nappy sometimes she flings her legs back into that position. She remembers it very well.” Lily believes her baby, who was born 7lb 8oz, might have become trapped in the strange position after she ran out of room in the womb to move her legs down. Although Willow was in a normal position at her 15 week scan, Lily had been told at every scan after that her daughter had her hands over her face. The mum has since realised that it was Willow’s feet covering her face – and can even spot it in her scan photos.  But Lily was terrified that moving her newborn’s legs might hurt her and was disappointed she couldn’t dress her up in any of the new babygrows she had bought for her arrival. Lily said: “I felt bad because I spent a fortune on all these little baby clothes and she couldn’t wear any of them. She could only wear vests because her legs wouldn’t go in anything. “She bent her knees the day after, but they were up at her side for about three weeks. “I struggled to hold her and couldn’t change her nappy. I didn’t even know where to begin.

title: celebrating austerity heroes met new
story: NewsopinionCelebrating our austerity heroes we met on the new road to Wigan PierOn the 10th anniversary of the collapse of Lehman Brothers, we’re marking the date with our own events – celebrating not bankers’ greed but the extraordinary spirit of the people who have spent a decade fighting backShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist18:56, 6 SEP 2018NewsopinionAnti-poverty activist Harry Leslie Smith at his old home "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt’s 10 years since the collapse of Lehman Brothers and scenes of bankers tearfully clearing their desks into cardboard cartons. Next week, to mark the anniversary, some ‘Lehman Brothers and Sisters’ are having a reunion cocktail and canapes party. Which is a funny way of remembering the moment they brought down a decade of vicious austerity onto the heads of those who did nothing to cause the crash and could least afford to pay for it. As the campaign 10 Years On puts it – “the banks got bailed out to the tune of &pound130 billion of our money, while we got sold out by austerity”. So, next week, we’re marking the 10-year anniversary with our own events – celebrating not bankers’ greed but the extraordinary spirit of the people who have spent a decade fighting back.  The ‘ordinary’ people who have run food banks and soup kitchens, supported family and friends, and resisted welfare cuts, insecure jobs and stagnant wages. Our events – on Sunday at Sunshine House Community Centre in Wigan and on Tuesday at the People’s History Museum in Manchester – will tell the stories of the people who were the collateral damage, through our Wigan Pier Project. Cleaners, nurses, lollipop ladies. Disabled and elderly people. Warehouse workers, fast food servers. Everyday people. Our Wigan Pier journey – inspired by George Orwell’s expedition eight decades ago through the Depression-hit Midlands and North – began in January 2017 when we set off from a cold Birmingham back street where a homeless man had died overnight. The last 20 months have been an extraordinary experience for me and colleagues Claire Donnelly and Andy Stenning – recorded at wiganpierproject.  We have spent months chatting to people in doorways, homeless shelters, food banks, community centres, bus stops and in their freezing, damp homes. I’ll never forget the man sobbing with bandaged arms  in the Portakabin food bank in  Staffordshire.  Or Rita Culshaw, the former ‘pit brow lass’, whose job it was as a young girl to sort coal from dirt. Or taking veteran campaigner Harry Leslie Smith back to the slum in Barnsley where he lived after his dad lost his job down the pit.  The people we’ve met are literally my Real Britain. Generous, kind, warm-hearted people who share what little they have. People who volunteer with kids, support newly arrived refugees, spend hours sorting food bank shelves or drive elderly people to the doctors. People like the wonderful staff and volunteers at Wigan’s Sunshine House. We started out with a copy of Orwell’s Road to Wigan Pier, now held together with Sellotape, determined to try to live up to that great writer’s capacity for empathy and insight. But also to do some things he wasn’t able to in 1936. To let people speak directly through video and first-person stories in their own voice. And, also, to try to forge a relationship with Wigan itself, a town that has felt itself in the shadow of that book all these years. After we set out, my dad told me that his granddad – another George – had apparently come from Wigan, but almost nothing was known about his life before he ended up in North Wales where his daughter, my nainie, was born.

title: council only resurfaces posh end
story: NewsCouncil only resurfaces posh end of street - stopping where a wall once divided rich and poorThe renovations ended at the spot where a wall once divided council houses from the richShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySarah Ward16:46, 6 SEP 2018Updated16:53, 6 SEP 2018NewsWentworth street and Aldrich Road where the Oxford Council has resurfaced the road up to the point where a wall once stood separating poor and wealthy "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA council has been accused of reigniting a ‘class war’ after only resurfacing the posh end of a street - to the spot where a wall once divided council houses from the rich. The suburban street is one long road split into two ends - where the wealthy Wentworth Road meets the more down at heel Aldrich Road. The developer who built the road and the estate in 1934 put a wall keep them apart - and even put spikes on the top. Following a row with Oxford City Council the wall was taken down 60 years ago in Sunnymead, Cutteslowe, Oxon. But now a stark reminder of the haves and have-nots appeared on the road - as workers repaired only the posh end of the street in gleaming black tarmac.  They left the other half untouched - and the dividing line is where the wall once stood. Now a vandal armed with a spray can added their own addition - the words ‘class war’ sprayed in block capitals in bright blue paint. Naomi Langlais, who lives on the working class side of the street, said: It was around April or May time that they decided the 'middle class' side deserved to be resurfaced. So we waited patiently for our end to be resurfaced too and thought it was just taking time as they had run out of money or something. But we soon realised it was just the one end they were doing, apparently we should put up with potholes and uneven surfacing.  She said neighbours had long joked about ‘class war’ on the street, and attributed the graffiti to what she perceived to be differing treatment from the highways team. Ms Langlais added: We have not moved on at all - now we have a visual divide but much less obvious one. The mum-of-four added: It is just so weird it stops at the exact spot that used to occupy the wall, half way down the road. The resurfacing is desperately needed on our end as well. “It does make you feel second class and it is no longer a council estate, people have paid a lot of money for houses this end.    A plaque now sits on the house which neighboured the wall, and reads: “Here stood one of the two Cutteslowe Walls erected 1934 and finally demolished on March 9, 1959.”  Oxford City Council said the only reason that its services company only resurfaced one side of the divide was that the two streets – Wentworth and Aldrich – are still classed as separate roads. A spokesman for the city council said: Oxford Direct Services resurfaced Wentworth Road earlier this year.

story: NewsFilm memorabilia auction featuring Indiana Jones' hat, Harry Potter's wand and Star Wars props in £3m saleLondon's IMAX BFI will host the UK's largest film prop auction later this monthShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly17:51, 6 SEP 2018Updated18:12, 6 SEP 2018NewsHarrison Ford's iconic Indiana Jones Signature Fedora hat has an estimate of £200,000 to £300,000 "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Iconic movie memorabilia - including Indiana Jones’ hat and bullwhip and Harry Potter's wand - is expected to fetch more than &pound3 million at Britain's largest film and TV prop auction this month. title: girl 9 ranked one best
story: NewsGirl, 9, killed by allergic reaction to dairy was ranked one of the best tennis players in UK for her ageSadie Bristow started feeling unwell on a family day out at Whitstable Castle in Kent last month and was airlifted to hospitalShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByStian Alexander19:30, 6 SEP 2018Updated19:34, 6 SEP 2018NewsSadie Bristow was considered a tennis prodigy"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA nine-year-old girl - ranked the best tennis player for her age in the UK - has died from a severe allergic reaction. Sadie Bristow was on a family day out at Whitstable Castle in Kent, when she told parents Stewart and Clare that she wasn't feeling well on August 19. Her parents rushed her to a medical centre in Whitstable and she was taken to the the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Margate in a critical condition before being airlifted to St George's Hospital in London. The nine-year-old - who had gone into anaphylactic shock, caused by an allergy to dairy products - however, died the following day. Writing online, her parents said that Sadie, a pupil at Chartham Primary School in Chatham, near Canterbury in Kent - died on August 20 and that her ‘infectious smile’ would be missed by all who knew her.  Dad Stewart, 45, who teaches tennis at the King's School Recreation Centre in Canterbury and the Bridge Tennis Club in Bridge, Kent - where Sadie played - wrote on a Just Giving page set up in Sadie's name : “Sadie was an inspiration and we wish to carry on inspiring in her name. “Sadie, at the end of the 2018 summer season, was ranked no1 UK under 9 girl. “Her passion, drive and determination got her there and we will do all we can in the same spirit to set up a charitable organisation or foundation in her name. “To carry on with her passion in tennis. To aid allergy understanding, research and prevention. “We will update as soon as we know what direction everything will take. If anyone has any advice, can offer any assistance please do contact us. “Thank you ever so much to everyone. The donations so generously given here will help us hugely and we are so ever grateful for the support and love that is giving us courage.  It will help immensely for us to get back together. All our love, Stewart, Clare, Charlotte and April xx. So far &pound17,000 has been raised of an initial target of just &pound1,000. Speaking to the Kent Messenger newspaper this week, Mr Bristow - who also has two other children, Charlotte, 11, and April, just one - said: She was just playing outside when she came in and told us she wasn't well. We decided she needed to go to hospital and took her to the Estuary View Medical Centre in Whitstable because it was a the quickest and from there she went to Margate Hospital and then St George's. Anaphylactic shock shuts down the airways very quickly and she did not respond to treatment with 16 shots of adrenaline, which is the first course of action. It is very rare and I think even the doctors we're taken aback by the speed of it. Sadie's funeral took place last week. The youngster won more than 40 regional and county tournaments last year, and was being fast-tracked by the Lawn Tennis Association.  The JustGiving website set up to raise money for the family - which has already raised more than &pound17,000 in donations - stated that Sadie was 'taken too early'. It pays tribute to the youngster, stating: “The world lost an amazing young girl on Monday 20th August. Sadie Bristow tragically died as a result of a severe allergic reaction. “In her short life she lived to the max at all times. Her infectious smile and lovable nature will be missed by so many.” Stewart, Clare, Charlotte, April and their family are devastated at this terrible time. Stewart spent so many hours on the tennis court with Sadie. She was equally competent by his side on the ski slopes. It's going to be hard for him to return to those same tennis courts and carry on.

title: international netball player 27 headaches
story: NewsSuperfit British sports star, 27, died of brain tumour just two weeks after getting terrible headaches on holidayCatherine Roberts, from Blackwood, South Wales, started suffering from headaches while on holiday in New Zealand and died just two weeks after arriving home to the UKShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill11:24, 6 SEP 2018Updated16:20, 6 SEP 2018NewsInternational netball player Catherine Roberts died of a brain tumour two weeks after experiencing headaches on holiday "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA superfit sportswoman died aged just 27 after being diagnosed with a brain tumour while on holiday. International netball player Catherine Roberts was travelling around New Zealand when she started suffering from headaches. She then went to see a doctor - and a scan revealed a lump on her brain. Catherine's mum - also called Catherine - flew out to New Zealand to join her daughter and they flew back to Britain together. But on her return doctors told her she was too ill for treatment, and tragically Catherine died just two weeks after landing back in the UK.  Catherine was with her fianc&eacutee Bryony Powell, also 27, and believed she had an iron deficiency when she began to suffer from headaches. Heartbroken Bryony said: She was very healthy and active so it was not normal for her to have a headache. They thought she was low on iron then a few days later we were on a bike ride and she became really confused. That was the first major sign that something was wrong.” Catherine, of Blackwood, South Wales, had played netball for Wales - and was described as fit and healthy when she set off on the dream trip. Catherine underwent surgery in New Zealand but was told she suffered from glioblastoma - an extremely aggressive form of brain cancer.  Bryony said: Where the tumour was located is the personality part of the brain and while in New Zealand she hadn’t cried, and she was quite an emotional person. She just said it was because she was having a great time, in hindsight that was the only symptom she had. Catherine was fit and healthy, the symptoms were things that people wouldn’t necessarily checked. She was tired, had headaches, confusion and a slight change in personality. Bryony wants people to now get checked as soon as they notice a change in their own symptoms.  She said: It’s really hard to process what happened and to be without her every day. The family is just devastated, we all are. We are trying to get each other through. It was tough. She was such a positive person, we never thought the worst would happen. We got engaged and we were inseparable. It is really hard to be without her.  Friends have now launched a netball tournament in memory of Catherine, of Blackwood, South Wales, which will raise money for The Brain Tumour Charity. Together with other friends they have raised more than &pound3,000 in Catherine's name since she died in May. Tournament organiser Vicki Randall said: We wanted to something for her and she would have liked a tournament.

title: kiss him hes 10 minutes
story: News'Kiss him... he's got 10 minutes': Dad reveals horrific moment doctors told him baby son was about to dieLittle Ted Drummond was already battling leukaemia when he was struck down with e-coli on a family holiday - fortunately he pulled through his ordeal and is now 10 years oldShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByRICHARD JENKINSSophie Evans15:21, 6 SEP 2018Updated17:06, 6 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/meet-ted-child-who-first-13203309,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dad has revealed the devastating moment doctors advised him to kiss his toddler son on the head and told him: He's got ten minutes left. John Drummond and his wife, Sarah, were told to expect the worst after their beloved little boy, Ted, was struck down with e-coli on a family holiday. Doctors said the 18-month-old, who was already battling leukaemia, was unlikely to be strong enough to fight the potentially-lethal combination. Warned he was about to die, the heartbroken parents were told to kiss their son goodbye - with medics believing he could have just 10 minutes to live.  John, from Basildon, Essex, recalled: Ted started going downhill quickly because the e-coli turned into sepsis , which obviously is lethal. A team of doctors and nurses were trying to put needles into his legs, his arms, his neck. It was two o'clock in the morning and the doctor told us: 'You've got to leave the room, we're going to put him into a medically induced coma. Kiss him on the head, he's got 10 minutes left'. Fortunately, after fighting for his life through the night, the brave little boy pulled through - but his battle with cancer was far from over. He spent two years in and out of hospital battling leukaemia. He had to endure more than 600 days in isolation and four blocks of intensive chemotherapy before eventually being given the all-clear.  Now aged 10, Ted is an ambassador for Beads of Courage, a programme set up by his family and funded by Children with Cancer UK from next year. The scheme helps children fighting the disease by giving them beads specifically coloured to mark each treatment, tablet and procedure. Ted was originally diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemia  at just six months old following a series of trips to the doctor's. John said: About two to three months before him being diagnosed we noticed his development was regressing. We were told it was an ear infection, or a bug, or a virus, or growing pains - or even that he was just attention seeking. After his parents sought a second opinion, Ted was diagnosed with ALL, which has a 50 per cent mortality rate in infants.  But his condition took a turn for the worse at 18 months when he was hit by e-coli while the family were holidaying in Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria. After two days Ted started getting ill, John recalled. We took him to the hospital and he had a rash and was getting really red. John and Sarah were told their son had e-coli. He ended up at London's Great Ormond Street Hospital, joined by his worried parents, but thankfully pulled through his ordeal. However, despite later being given the all-clear from cancer, Ted had to endure further treatments throughout his childhood. Only now has he been downgraded to a yearly check-up. Speaking of how Beads for Courage helped Ted, John said: The beads are how Ted tells people the story of his childhood oncology.  For every blood transfusion you get a red bead. You get a white bead that relates to chemotherapy. Ted has 600 lime beads for isolation, and hundreds of black beads - one for every time he had a needle stuck into him. The Beads of Courage programme is a phenomenal positive reinforcement tool. They don't just look pretty, they serve a really good purpose. And the amount of hope and support they give to children is immeasurable. We pinch ourselves sometimes and ask why this wasn't here 20 years ago? We would have benefited from it. But it's here now, and every child in the UK who has got cancer has now got that access.

title: meghan markle dazzles blue holds
story: NewsMeghan Markle dazzles in blue as she holds hands with Prince Harry at concert marking end of WW1 centenaryThe one-off concert is a night of music and reflection in aid of three charities Help for Heroes, Combat Stress and Heads TogetherShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByDanya BazaraaNews Reporter20:21, 6 SEP 2018NewsThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex arriving at the 100 Days to Peace gala music evening "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex held hands as they arrived at a music festival marking the centenary of the end of the First World War. Meghan Markle dazzled in a bright blue dress, flowing to below her knees and teamed with stilettos of the same colour for the 100 Days to Peace gala music evening.  Holding a clutch, the former actress walked alongside Prince Harry, dressed in a navy suit with an olive green tie as they arrived at Central Hall Westminster, London.  Presented by the Royal Armouries, the one-off concert is an evening of music and reflection in aid of three charities Help for Heroes, Combat Stress and Heads Together. During the intermission, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle will meet some of the performers during a reception in the Presidents Room. The royals will also meet with representatives from the three charities, and the Royal Armouries' Trustees and Sponsors.  During the concert, Sir Karl Jenkins, one of the most performed living composers in the world, will conduct his internationally-acclaimed 'The Armed Man: A Mass for Peace'.  Performed by the Royal Choral Society and the Philharmonia Orchestra with a solo by Kathryn Rudge, this will be the only performance of one of his best loved works in England in 2018, to be conducted by Sir Karl himself.  The music will be performed against a backdrop of Hefin Owen’s film of 'The Armed Man'. In addition to hosting the evening, Lesley Garrett will perform two songs, poignant reminders of the First World War.  Her first performance, 'He Wishes for the Cloths of Heaven' is a WB Yeats poem published in 1899.  Lesley will also be singing the opening lines from 'For the Fallen'.  Help for Heroes provide lifelong support to Service Personnel and Military Veterans with injuries, illnesses and wounds sustained while serving in the British Armed Forces. Combat Stress offers therapeutic and clinical community and residential treatment to former members of the British Armed Forces who are suffering from a range of mental health conditions. Heads Together is a mental health initiative spearheaded by The Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and The Duke of Sussex which combines a campaign to tackle stigma and change the conversation on mental health with fundraising for a series of innovative new mental health services.  The concert tonight comes after Meghan and Harry, who married in May, were among the star-studded guest list for the annual WellChild Awards on Tuesday evening. The couple dressed to impress and both wore suits for the glittering occasion at the Royal Lancaster Hotel in London. They celebrated the inspiring qualities of some of the country's seriously ill young people and the dedication of those who go the extra mile to keep children healthy and happy. At the event, Harry presented an award and gave a heartwarming speech. While Meghan proved she’s every inch the perfect princess with a touching gesture to poorly seven-year-old Matilda Booth, who gave her a bunch of flowers The Duchess picked a white rose out and gave it back to Matilda and told her to keep in her memory box, leaving the youngster beaming from ear-to-ear.

title: novichok assassins calmly strolled through
story: NewsRussian assassins stroll through Salisbury and window shop for vintage COINS moments after Novichok attackAlexander Petrov and Ruslan Bochirov travelled from London to Salisbury where they sprayed Novichok on the Skripals' doorknobShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill15:07, 6 SEP 2018Updated16:50, 6 SEP 2018NewsAlexander Petrov and Ruslan Bochirov were seen strolling through Salisbury and window shopping vintage coins minutes after Novichok attack "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe two Russian Novichok assassins were seen calmly walking through Salisbury and even stopped to look at some vintage coins minutes after their deadly nerve agent attack. Footage shows Alexander Petrov and Ruslan Bochirov strolling through the town moments after they allegedly tried to murder former spy Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia by spraying Novichok of their doorknob. The pair walk past Dauwalders collectables and stamp store before stopping to look in the window. Both are dressed in winter coats with Perov sporting a backpack and black woolly hat while Boshirov is wearing a baseball cap and a dark jacket.  They can be seen chatting about the wares in the window and try to enter the store before realising it's closed. After being unable to go into the shop, they then make their way to the train station and head to London. Paul Dauwalder, who owns the shop, told Mail Online : They seemed quite bungling, to be honest. The coins aren't the valuable ones, we wouldn't keep them in the window. It was a Sunday and they had just attempted a murder, but they still tried to come in the shop. They were obviously coin fans. They might be murderers but that doesn't mean they are intellectually dead. From the way they were behaving, they looked like coin enthusiasts or collectors. It seems we even attract Russian murderers.  Their actions in Salisbury almost resulted in the deaths of the Skripals and weeks later caused the hospitalisation of Charlie Rowley and the death of Dawn Sturgess. The Mirror revealed today that the highly trained killers are part of the &shyKremlin’s sinister GRU . British military intelligence sources told the Mirror it is feared Petrov and Bochirov have practised nerve agent attacks for months before the Salisbury operation. We also learned the pair are likely to have been on undercover missions across the West, Europe and Britain several times before they came in March.  The two crack soldiers – recruited from the Red Army and trained for years to gather &shyintelligence on enemy forces and launch kill missions – were last night in hiding in Russia. Their commanders are thought to control Russia’s nerve agent stockpile and its nuclear capability, contained in a briefcase carried by military chiefs and President Vladimir Putin. Despite the Kremlin’s denials it is believed the pair – whose names are aliases – will have been hailed heroes after successfully escaping.  One ex-British military &shyintelligence source told the Mirror: “They almost killed Sergei Skripal in an operation in which they did little to hide their movements. “It is a classic GRU operation, not terribly subtle, but bold and it carried a message that says to all of Putin’s enemies, ‘You are not safe anywhere – we will hunt you down and get to you eventually’. “This was a political offensive operation and it is deeply worrying that they didn’t try to hide it. “They have tested our reaction, gambled against Britain having support and got that wrong but they know more about our strengths and weaknesses – so it was a success. There is little doubt the GRU has been practising this method of using nerve agents to kill, among other &shytechniques, in less carefully policed arenas than Britain, like Syria and perhaps even the Ukraine.  “We should be deeply concerned that the GRU appears to have control of Russia’s Novichok supply as well. It could mean the domestic security forces have relinquished control of it.” Intelligence analyst Bruce Jones added: “These two were probably expendable as the operation was almost in plain sight and not without its risks but the GRU were striking against one of their own. “Sergei Skripal, as a former GRU officer, is regarded as a traitor because he spied for MI6 so in some ways this operation was a matter of honour.

title: odd highway code loophole driving
story: AdvertorialOdd Highway Code loophole about driving a car in the dark is leaving motorists baffledBizarre rule applies in brightly-lit 30mph zones - but there's a catchShare&nbspByDave Masters09:48, 4 SEP 2018Updated09:19, 6 SEP 2018AdvertorialMost motorists won't have heard of this"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribingSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs the weather changes, there are a few things drivers need to know about their cars and driving. The law on lights is simple enough: you must use car headlights from half an hour after sunset until half an hour before sunrise. But there is a surprising exception to this rule. If you're travelling under 30mph in a brightly-lit area, you don't legally have to have them on - though you do still need your sidelights. It's an odd quirk of the law, but is it recommended? It's generally agreed that using dipped headlights at night is always the best option - making you more visible to other road users as well as improving your view of the road ahead. But if you do choose to use just your sidelights, make sure you don't fall foul of the rules - or you risk a &pound50 fine. Not a bright idea. Make sure you know the rules  It's absolutely crucial that, at all times of the year, your car has a full set of working lights.  As well as an MOT failure, driving with a faulty or damaged light could mean a fixed penalty notice, or three points on the driving licence plus a bigger fine if it goes to court .   Since 2011, it's also been a legal requirement for all new cars sold in the EU to have daytime running lights . The new UK MOT rules mean that cars registered after March 2018 will need to have these working to pass the test.  Research has shown that DRLs are likely to reduce multiple vehicle daytime accidents and fatalities by up to 6% once all vehicles are equipped.   If you don't have DRLs on your car, then it's acceptable to leave your sidelights on all the time. Many cars will automatically turn sidelights on if they have an auto mode for lights, they will also switch to dipped lights when its sensor feels it's dark enough. The law states that you need your dipped headlights on between sunset and sunrise - but there's no harm turning them on early to improve your visibility to other road users. Check your lights regularly  The best way to do this is with a friend who can confirm that the reverse and brake lights are all working. Alternatively, you can use a reflective surface like a garage door. You can check hazard/indicator lights yourself as well as the running lights and dipped/main beam settings. If you notice a bulb isn't working, then pop to Halfords - they will select and fit replacement bulbs to your car for a small fee, and there's no need to book beforehand.  For a more comprehensive check that everything is working as it should, make an appointment online or in-store for a Free Car Check . As well as a bulb check, they'll also check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. They'll even give you a free screenwash top-up!  Don't be dazzled  As nights get earlier we all have to contend with headlights dazzling us. Remember that most rearview mirrors these days offer protection from bright lights from behind. On newer cars you'll often have an auto-dimming mirror - which means you just let it protect you from being distracted by overly-bright lights. If you find yourself struggling to see, you'll notice an off switch to disable the feature. On older cars it's common that your rear view mirror will have a small mechanical switch underneath it. Flip that and the mirror will change angle, without adjusting the view you see. This is used to stop you from being dazzled in the same way a modern electric system works.  If your car has an old manual mirror then why not upgrade to an EchoMaster Dynamic Mirror and Reversing Camera Kit  for &pound149. A reversing camera is fitted behind your number plate by a bracket. This rearview mirror also auto-dims, perfect for autumn driving! Halfords will also fit the whole system for &pound75.  Keep your car clean  A dirty car looks bad, but it might also get you in to trouble. The law states that your number plate needs to be clean and visible at all times. You also need to make sure that brake lights are clean and clearly visible.  As well as using a good car cleaner you should also make sure your windscreen and lights are clean. Use a specialist glass cleaning product like Autoglym Car Glass Polish , &pound8. You can pair that with the Demon Car Valet Pack  - priced &pound24.50  to get every part of your car shiny as new.
